text: [APPLAUSE]
My name is Steve Keller.

I'm a lung transplant
physician at Brigham
and Women's Hospital.

And I care for patients
with advanced lung failure.

Lung failure is the third
leading cause of death

in the United
States and globally.

It has unleashed
literally, a tsunami

of patients with respiratory
failure into our hospitals.

The only option I have to
care for these patients

when they present
to the hospital

is to put a breathing
tube into their throats.

Connect them to a mechanical
ventilator in an effort
to try to keep them alive.

More than 50% of my patients
have passed away at six months.

There has got to
be a better way.

And that is what has motivated
us, at X-Cor Therapeutics,

to design and develop a novel
therapeutic device to pave

the way for future
care of patients
with respiratory failure.

With this device, we can
supplant lung function
using blood flow.

So imagine instead of
full heart lung bypass

and taking a full cardiac
output out of the neck

through a central line, we can
treat Steve's patient using

vivo venous blood flow from
a peripheral vein, which

means that a patient
can get almost,
like, a dialysis-like workflow.

Which is much easier for
hospitals to sustain.

It's much more
economical for hospitals

to actually be able to
afford it and distribute it
on a mass scale.

And we've traveled all
over the entire world

to find a supply chain to be
able to build this device.

With clinical data, which
we're going to try and achieve

next year, we'll be able to
prove that this device can

promote extubations, which
is removing that ventilator
tube earlier.

And discharge
those patients home

so they can lead
healthier lives.
Thanks.
[APPLAUSE]
